fields.description:
This appears to have happened after very quick scripted turn-arounds on 'run' then 'terminate' for pairs of instances. 
This eutester script immediately terminates and deletes resources if a fault in the test is detected to clean up the test. In this case I was passing in bad data to the script so instances would run and then almost immediately get terminated. The end result is all IPs are now associated with terminated instances. Attaching clc cloud-output and error logs, but I also have all other clc and cc logs saved off if needed. 
 
All addresses could be manually dis-associated/released.


Thanks, 
-M


{code}
[root@eucahost-51-75 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-addresses 
ADDRESS	192.168.40.37	i-8AEC43F6 (arn:aws:euare::000000000000:user/eucalyptus)	standard
ADDRESS	192.168.40.38	i-C0FA4151 (arn:aws:euare::000000000000:user/eucalyptus)	standard
ADDRESS	192.168.40.39	i-079B4103 (arn:aws:euare::000000000000:user/eucalyptus)	standard
ADDRESS	192.168.40.44	i-B9294497 (arn:aws:euare::000000000000:user/eucalyptus)	standard
[root@eucahost-51-75 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-instances 
[root@eucahost-51-75 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-availability-zones verbose
AVAILABILITYZONE	PARTI00	192.168.51.76 arn:euca:eucalyptus:PARTI00:cluster:CC_76/
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- vm types	free / max   cpu   ram  disk
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.small	0008 / 0008   1    512     5
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.medium	0004 / 0004   2    512    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.large	0004 / 0004   2   1024    15
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.xlarge	0002 / 0002   2   2048    20
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.xlarge	0002 / 0002   4   4096    20

{code}

After disassociating each address and attempting to run a new instance...

{code}
[root@eucahost-51-75 ~]# euca-describe-addresses 
ADDRESS	192.168.40.37	available (arn:aws:euare::000000000000:user/eucalyptus)	standard
ADDRESS	192.168.40.38	available (arn:aws:euare::000000000000:user/eucalyptus)	standard

[root@eucahost-51-75 ~]# euca-describe-instances

fields.summary: Addresses remain associated with terminated instances

comments.body: gzip'd clc cloud-output.log and cloud-error.log

FWIW, I have seen the same behavior when running eutester4j terminate instance test which basically starts then immediately terminates an instance, however, in my case manually releasing did not resolve the issue. I found a work around is to restart the clc and the addresses will be free and available.
Can you provide exact steps to reproduce this issue?
Please point me to the eutester script that was running when you saw this issue.
[~mmunn1] eutester4j and the test I referenced is not yet checked in. i do not know which test [~mclark] was using.

Here's a sample barebones ipython session using eutester's "testing" branch. This reproduces it for me pretty easily.
Lemme know if you need any help reproducing. 
Thanks!
-M

{code}
from eucaops import Eucaops

#Get eutester obj...
tester = Eucaops(config_file='75.conf', password='foobar')

#Get a key...
#key = tester.add_keypair('mattkey') 
#or get existing key present in local dir...
key = tester.get_all_current_local_keys()[0]

#get an instance-store emi...
emi = tester.get_emi(root_device_type='instance-store')

def bug():
    ins = tester.run_image(image=emi, keypair=key, max=4, monitor_to_running=False, clean_on_fail=True)
    for i in ins:
        print 'killing instance: '+str(i.id)
        i.terminate()
    return ins

#keep running bug() until problem pops up. For me took a handful of tries. 

{code}

Hi Mike, 
Sure I was able to reproduce this on another system with the following topo. Lemme know if/when you have a system that's free and I can try there as well. 
Thanks!
-Matt

{code}
192.168.51.77	CENTOS	6.3	64	REPO	[CLC WS]
192.168.51.81	CENTOS	6.3	64	REPO	[SC00 CC00]
192.168.51.90	CENTOS	6.3	64	REPO	[NC00]

{code}

Pretty small window for this race condition. Notice the 'age@status' column from the following test. 0 when this bug is exposed. 3-9 seconds on the system that cannot reproduce this. 2nd question is why the 3-9 second delay/difference between the two systems?

System(s) which reproduces the fault:

Ok, based on what we know of this issue right now we don't want to target 3.2.1.   Changing target version.

Seeing this on 10.101.1.15 running :

eucalyptus-cloud-3.2.1-0.0.496.20130123git3833a2af.el6.x86_64

It just started on Monday after I updated .

John, can you add a little more detail regarding how you saw this issue?  Was this due to a small window of time between the run and terminate of the instance as [~mclark] mentioned: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-4735?focusedCommentId=38979&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-38979
I have two DC clusters that experience the problem very frequently  launching bfebs imagee for defect https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-4562. i will include the script in this defect.
Script to loop bfebs images.

too large to upload to jira .
Seeing this in automated QA runs.

It looks like the issue in the 3.3 QA run has a slightly different cause. For the originally reported issue (as I understand it) the problem is with instances going from pending -> shutting down, in 3.3 is appears that the issue is with instances going from running -> shutting down. 

I believe I have reproduced the issue that occurs in 3.3 QA runs, but it is quite possible it is a separate issue:

{code}
# euca-run-instances emi-XXXXXXXX; for N in {1..1000}; do ID=$(euca-describe-instances --filter instance-state-name=running | grep INSTANCE | awk '{print $2}'); if [ ! -z "$ID" ] ; then euca-terminate-instances $ID; fi; sleep 0.05; done
{code}

this should be used with no instances running, it will terminate any (visible) running instances! This will run an instance and terminate it as soon as it enters the "running" state. As before, the instance shows no association between the instance and address but the address shows as assigned to the instance.

When addresses enter this state it is possible to disassociate and then release them (release by itself does not work, not sure if this would work for a regular user or only the cloud administrator)

[~sjones]

Can we just change the default?

We could just change the default to address the issue found in 3.3 QA testing. I would not recommend that as a fix though, much better to fix the cloud controller so it will successfully retry the unassignment and fix the cluster controller so it does not take 60 seconds to respond (the attached patch shows all changes necessary to fix the cloud controller issues)
Resolved in the 3.3.0 release
